awd_titl_txt: Black-Hole Spin Precession and its Astrophysical Implications
awd_abstract_narration:
Gravity is one of the four fundamental forces of nature and is described by Einstein's theory of general relativity.  One of the most extreme predictions of general relativity is the existence of black holes, compact objects whose gravity is so intense that not even light can escape from them. Investigating gravity in such an extreme regime provides one of the most promising opportunities to learn more about this fundamental force. Another prediction of general relativity, that binary black holes emit gravitational waves that stretch and squeeze spacetime, was recently confirmed by the NSF-funded Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO).  Black holes are fully described by their masses and spins, but the spins of binary black holes are generally misaligned with their orbital plane, much like the 23 degree misalignment between the Earth's rotation axis and its orbit about the Sun responsible for the seasons. General relativity causes black-hole spins to change direction or precess; this precession leaves detectable signatures in the gravitational waves observed by LIGO. This award supports studies on black-hole spin precession and the extent to which it can be constrained by gravitational-wave detectors like LIGO. This work helps scientists to interpret LIGO observations and thus better understand gravity and the astrophysical origin of black holes responsible for their spin misalignments. The PI and collaborators will also develop an interactive virtual-reality simulation of precessing black holes and the gravitational waves they emit which will be available free online and presented at local public libraries and museums through existing outreach networks of the University of Texas at Dallas. These simulations help the public virtually experience the effects of gravitational waves and enhance public interest and support for science research and education.

This goal of this proposal is to provide a comprehensive picture of the origin and implications of misalignments between binary black-hole spins and their orbital angular momentum. Population-synthesis codes will be used to explore how initial spin misalignments depend on various aspects of astrophysical black-hole formation like mass transfer, tidal alignment, and supernova recoils. The spin distributions generated by these codes will be evolved from black-hole formation until they begin to emit detectable gravitational waves using the PI's newly developed technique for efficiently calculating spin precession on the inspiral timescale. Once the binaries enter the sensitivity band of ground-based detectors like LIGO, publicly available codes in the LIGO Algorithm Library Suite will be used to generate waveforms and analyze how well the binary black-hole parameters that determine spin precession can be estimated for realistic signal-to-noise ratios. The PI and collaborators will also perform and analyze numerical-relativity simulations to assess the reliability of post-Newtonian predictions for spin precession in the final orbits before black-hole merger. This research provides the basis for astrophysical model selection, combining constraints on spin misalignments from many events to distinguish astrophysical models of black-hole formation, such as dynamical formation in a globular cluster (for which spins should be isotropic) versus formation from stellar binaries (which should exhibit a tendency towards aligned spins). The final project will consider how spin precession between black hole formation and merger affects predictions for final black-hole masses, spins, and gravitational recoils.  This project has implications both for the stellar-mass black holes observed by LIGO and recoiling quasars spatially or kinematically offset from their host galaxies sought in galaxy surveys.

por.por_cntn:
Black holes, massive objects so compact that even light cannot escape from within their event horizons, are a fundamental prediction of Einstein?s theory of general relativity.  They can form binary systems in which two black holes orbit each other.  Each black hole can spin about its rotation axis, and these spins can be misaligned with the orbital plane of the binary (like the 23.5 degree misalignment responsible for the Earth?s seasons).  Spin-orbit and spin-spin coupling within general relativity can cause these misaligned black-hole spins and the binary orbital angular momentum to change direction or ?precess? with time.  The research supported by NSF award PHY-1607031 investigated this precession and how it could arise in models of astrophysical binary black-hole formation.  It resulted in 13 refereed publications, some highlights of which are summarized below.

A new multi-timescale approach to calculate the time evolution of black-hole spins was developed and a publicly available code PRECESSION that implements this approach was released.  This approach led to the discovery of resonances between the frequencies of precession (the orbital angular momentum rotating about the total angular momentum) and nutation (oscillation of the angle between the orbital and total angular momenta).  These nutational resonances cause the total angular momentum to tilt as the binary black holes inspiral due to gravitational-wave emission (see the green curve in Fig. 1).

Five new parameters to characterize precession of the orbital angular momentum were derived: the precession amplitude <θL>, the precession frequency <ΩL>, the nutation amplitude ΔθL, the nutation frequency ω, and the precession frequency variation ΔΩL.  Distributions of these parameters as functions of the black-hole mass ratio q and spin magnitudes χi are shown in Fig. 2.  Precession and nutation of the orbital angular momentum modulate the gravitational waves emitted as binary black holes inspiral towards merger, allowing them to be constrained in events observed by current and future gravitational-wave detectors like the LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA (LVK) network.  Constraints on the five new precession parameters in LVK event GW190412 are shown in Fig. 3.

The astrophysical origin of binary black holes determines the values of these five new precessional parameters.  A new model was developed for binary black-hole formation from stellar binaries.  This model helped identify Scenarios A and B of binary black-hole formation in which stable mass transfer (SMT) precedes or follows common-envelope evolution (CEE) when the two stars that will evolve into black holes lose their envelopes.  Each scenario is further divided into Pathways 1 and 2 depending on whether the loss of the second stellar envelope follows or proceeds the first collapse of a stellar core into a black hole. The four pathways (A1, A2, B1, B2) are shown in Fig. 4.  Each pathway gives rise to binary black holes experiencing different amounts of precession and nutation as characterized by the five new parameters.  Black holes in Pathway A1 need to inherit spin from their stellar progenitors to precess, while those in Pathway A2 and Scenario B can acquire misaligned spins from tidal effects and mass transfer between the binary members respectively.

The effect of spin precession on supermassive black-hole binaries formed following galactic mergers was also investigated by applying the new multi-timescale approach to cosmological simulations of galactic mergers.  It was found that the smaller black hole in these binaries can more easily align its spin with the orbital angular through interaction with a gaseous disk surrounding the binary.  This condition causes the black-hole spins in the orbital plane to anti-align with each other (to angle ΔΦ of ?π radians as shown in Fig. 5).  This anti-alignment could potentially be observable by future space-based gravitational-wave detectors like the proposed LISA mission in the 2030?s.

This research has had a broader impact on society through the education it has provided to students and the outreach provided to the general public.  Two graduate students and four undergraduates at the PI?s home institution were first authors on publications that contributed to their doctoral dissertations and honors theses.  The PI and collaborators created the public outreach simulation Virtual Interaction with Gravitational waves to Observe Relativity (VIGOR).  This simulation, a screenshot of which is shown in Fig. 6, allows users to manipulate the masses and orbits of binary black holes and observe how this manipulation affects the distortion of an Earth-shaped test mass by the gravitational waves emitted by the binary.  This simulation is publicly available online and was presented to at venues including the Women in Physics (WIP) summer camps at the University of Texas at Dallas, the Conference for the Advancement of Science Teaching, and the Forum on Outreach and Engaging the Public at the April Meeting of the American Physical Society.  Outreach with VIGOR can hopefully increase engagement in STEM fields, particularly among students from underrepresented groups at the Texas schools at which it was presented.
